questions.text: A 39-year-old woman came to the office because of blurred vision for the past two months. The patient has also experienced difficulty chewing and swallowing. The symptoms worsen throughout the day and improve with rest. The patient works as a teacher and has had a great deal of stress lately. She does not smoke and drinks a glass of wine occasionally. She takes no medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg. Physical examination reveals bilateral ptosis. Muscle strength is decreased in both lower extremities. A lateral chest x-ray shows an anterior mediastinal mass. Electromyography shows a decremental response following repetitive nerve stimulation. Which of the following types of receptors is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Intracellular receptor with DNA-binding domain
Ion channel-linked receptor
Transmembrane receptor associated with tyrosine kinase activity
Membrane-bound G-protein coupled receptors
Transmembrane receptor causing activation of Janus kinase/STAT pathway

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with myasthenia gravis, which results from antibodies against postsynaptic nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.    

Nicotinic cholinergic receptors are ligand-gated ion channel receptors. When a specific ligand binds to the receptor, the channel opens to allow ions such as chloride, calcium, sodium, and potassium to flow into the cell, down their gradient passively, and trigger downstream signaling. Nicotinic cholinergic receptors participate in rapid signaling events in electrically active cells, such as neurons.  

Two other types of cell surface receptors include:  

G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR) are seven-pass transmembrane receptors that activate intracellular second messenger systems and guanine nucleotide-binding proteins (G proteins).  

- Enzyme-linked receptors are single-pass transmembrane proteins. The extracellular end of these receptors can bind ligands, whereas the intracellular portion has enzymatic activity. When a ligand binds to an enzyme-linked receptor, it triggers a conformational change in the enzymatic domain to form high-affinity binding sites for the second messengers. These messengers are phosphorylated by tyrosine kinase.  



Option Analysis

❌ Intracellular receptor with DNA-binding domain:
Incorrect: Steroid hormones, thyroid hormones, and vitamin D act by binding to intracellular receptors. The intracellular receptors contain DNA-binding domains, which enable them to interact with regulatory DNA sequences in target genes.
✅ Ion channel-linked receptor:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Transmembrane receptor associated with tyrosine kinase activity:
Incorrect: Insulin and insulin-like growth factors bind to transmembrane receptors that stimulate intracellular tyrosine kinase activity, initiating a downstream phosphorylation cascade.
❌ Membrane-bound G-protein coupled receptors:
Incorrect: G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) are transmembrane receptors that activate the intracellular second messenger systems when ligands bind to the extracellular receptor and activate guanine nucleotide-binding proteins (G proteins). It is utilized by the autonomic nervous systems and certain hormones, such as the parathyroid hormone.
❌ Transmembrane receptor causing activation of Janus kinase/STAT pathway:
Incorrect: Some cell surface receptors leading to activation of JAK as well as signal transducers and activators of transcription (STAT) protein. STAT then enters the nucleus and promotes gene transcription. These hormones using this signaling pathway include erythropoietin, prolactin, and growth hormones.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her partner due to progressive lethargy and confusion. The patient was recently diagnosed with metastatic small cell carcinoma of the lung and has refused all treatment, wishing to pursue only “comfort care measures.” She has been smoking a pack of cigarettes per day for the last 45 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show the following:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium   108 mEq/L 
 Potassium   4.2 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   0.9 mg/dL 
 Albumin   3.2 g/dL 

The patient is started on hypertonic saline. On the second day of treatment, the partner notices the patient is unable to move, but she is able to blink in response to questions. Which of the following is the most likely location of the brain lesion in this patient?

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Location A
Location B
Location C
Location D
Location E

questions.solution:
This patient has quadriplegia with sparing of eye blinking after correction of hyponatremia using hypertonic saline. She likely experienced central pontine myelinolysis.  

This patient’s hyponatremia developed secondary to ectopic antidiuretic hormone secretion by the underlying small cell lung cancer. In patients with hyponatremia, water moves from the blood into the brain, causing brain cells (primarily astrocytes) to swell. The brain cells are able to adapt to hyponatremia by losing inorganic (e.g., electrolytes) and organic (e.g., myoinositol, taurine, glutamine) osmolytes to reestablish normal cell volume.  

When patients are treated rapidly with hypertonic saline, the hyperosmolar environment causes reversal of the initial adaptation, with water flowing from cells into the intravascular space to achieve isotonicity. This results in rapid cellular dehydration; astrocytes and oligodendroglia do not have sufficient time to actively replace osmolytes within the cell, resulting in cellular apoptosis and death.   

The pons is particularly susceptible, and cell death here causes central pontine myelinolysis (also termed osmotic demyelination syndrome). Clinical features typically appear after 2-6 days of hypertonic saline treatment. Symptoms include quadriplegia and pseudobulbar palsy (dysfunction of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI), which can manifest with dysphagia and dysarthria. Central pontine myelinolysis can also cause locked-in syndrome, in which there is paralysis of most of the body’s voluntary muscles but with preservation of vertical eye movements and the ability to blink.   

Option Analysis

❌ Location A:
Incorrect: Lesions in the frontal lobe can present with disinhibition as well as deficits in concentration and orientation. However, frontal lobe lesions would not result in diffuse paralysis with sparing of eye blinking.
❌ Location B:
Incorrect: The corpus callosum connects the left and right cerebral hemispheres, enabling communication between the two halves. Lesions due to diseases in the corpus callosum are uncommon; however, in refractory epilepsy, treatment can include surgically severing the corpus callosum. 
❌ Location C:
Incorrect: Cerebellar lesions can result in ataxia. Lateral lesions affect voluntary movement of extremities whereas medial lesions (e.g. in the vermis) can result in truncal ataxia and nystagmus. This patient is presenting with quadriplegia, which cannot be accounted for by a cerebellar lesion alone.
✅ Location D:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Location E:
Incorrect: Lesions in the medulla can result in lateral medullary (Wallenburg) syndrome, which would present as ipsilateral paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI, as well as contralateral loss of pain and temperature. Quadriplegia, as seen in this patient, would be highly unlikely.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the office to evaluate intermittent painful double vision for three days. Her symptoms occur only when looking laterally. The patient has myopia and has been wearing corrective lenses for ten years. Ten days ago, the patient fell off her bike and was seen in the emergency department. During that visit, a head CT scan was performed and was unremarkable. Current medications include oral contraceptive pills. Vitals are within normal limits. On examination, the pupils are equal and reactive to light. Corrected visual acuity is 20/40 in each eye. The left eye abducts with attempted left gaze, but the right eye remains stationary. The right eye abducts and exhibits horizontal nystagmus with a rightward gaze, but the left eye remains stationary. The patient can converge both eyes without associated nystagmus. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral disc hyperemia. Injury to which of the following structures is the most likely etiology of this patient's ocular symptoms?

choices.text: Oculomotor nerve
Medial lemniscus
Medial longitudinal fasciculus
Dorsal midbrain
Abducens nerve

questions.solution:
This patient presents with characteristic adduction defects of internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) and hyperemia of the optic discs. Together, these findings indicate optic neuritis, one of the most common initial findings of multiple sclerosis (MS).

INO is a disorder of conjugate horizontal gaze. The affected eye cannot adduct, and the contralateral eye abducts with nystagmus; however, convergence and pupillary light reflexes are preserved. This condition is secondary to demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), which normally mediates communication between the CN III (oculomotor) and CN VI (abducens) nuclei to allow for coordinated horizontal eye movements. Unilateral MLF lesions often result from lacunar strokes in the pontine artery distribution, whereas bilateral MLF lesions are typically observed in patients with MS.  



Option Analysis

❌ Oculomotor nerve  :
Incorrect: Damage to the oculomotor nerve (CN III) leaves the actions of the lateral rectus and the superior oblique muscle unopposed, resulting in an abducted and depressed eye (“down and out”). Ptosis and mydriasis are often seen as well.  
❌ Medial lemniscus  :
Incorrect: A lesion of the medial lemniscus would result in contralateral loss of vibration, proprioception, and light touch.  
✅ Medial longitudinal fasciculus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dorsal midbrain  :
Incorrect: Damage to the dorsal midbrain can cause Parinaud syndrome, with impaired upgaze and dilated non-reactive pupils. Moreover, Parinaud syndrome is most commonly seen in patients with hydrocephalus or posterior midbrain lesions (e.g. pineal tumors); trauma is an infrequent cause of Parinaud syndrome.  
❌ Abducens nerve:
Incorrect: Abducens nerve damage results in isolated lateral rectus palsy and an inability to abduct the eye.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician due to slurred speech and difficulty swallowing. The patient’s symptoms started two weeks ago and have progressively worsened. In addition, she has noticed excessive drooling and difficulty chewing food. She was seen five years ago due to painful eye movements, decreased vision in the left eye, and associated left lower extremity weakness. She was started on a monoclonal antibody, which helped control her symptoms, but she later stopped using it due to the adverse effects. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals brisk jaw reflexes bilaterally and an exaggerated gag reflex. The patient bursts out into spontaneous laughter on multiple occasions during the encounter. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Demyelination of the bilateral corticobulbar tracts
Mass in the jugular foramen
Tumor affecting the bilateral nucleus ambiguus
Tumor affecting the right nucleus ambiguus
Demyelination of the distal aspect cranial nerve IX

questions.solution:
Pseudobulbar palsy is an upper motor neuron lesion involving the corticobulbar (supranuclear) pathways of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI. An upper motor neuron lesion occurs above the motor nuclei of the cranial nerves. Pseudobulbar palsy is caused by bilateral damage to the corticobulbar tracts. Causes of the condition include amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), strokes, traumatic brain injury, neoplasm, and multiple sclerosis (as is the likely diagnosis in this patient).  

The clinical presentation of pseudobulbar palsy includes dysphagia, dysarthria, dysphonia, and an increased gag reflex. Patients may also show signs of emotional lability and apathy. Of note, while the gag reflex is exaggerated in pseudobulbar palsy (upper motor neuron lesion), it is typically absent in bulbar palsy (lower motor neuron lesion). This difference is a key clinical sign used to distinguish between bulbar and pseudobulbar palsy.  



Option Analysis

✅ Demyelination of the bilateral corticobulbar tracts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mass in the jugular foramen:
Incorrect: A mass in the jugular foramen can compress cranial nerves IX, X, and XI and result in bulbar palsy. Bulbar palsy can manifest with weakness in the muscles supplied by these nerves and an absent gag reflex since it is a lower motor neuron lesion. However, emotional lability (inappropriate laughter) is not seen in patients with bulbar palsy. 
❌ Tumor affecting the bilateral nucleus ambiguus :
Incorrect: The nucleus ambiguus contains the motor nuclei of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI. A lesion affecting this structure will lead to bulbar palsy, resembling pseudobulbar palsy. However, reflexes are diminished, and emotional lability is absent in patients with bulbar palsy. 
❌ Tumor affecting the right nucleus ambiguus:
Incorrect: The nucleus ambiguus contains the motor nuclei for CN IX, X, and XI. A lesion affecting this structure will lead to bulbar palsy, resembling pseudobulbar palsy. However, reflexes are diminished, and emotional lability is absent in patients with bulbar palsy. 
❌ Demyelination of the distal aspect cranial nerve IX:
Incorrect: This patient has an exaggerated gag reflex, suggestive of an upper motor neuron lesion. In contrast, demyelination of the peripheral portions of the cranial nerves outside the skull will result in lower motor neuron symptoms, such as decreased reflexes.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 2-day history of blurry vision in the left eye and pain with eye movement. She had an episode of urinary incontinence several months ago that resolved spontaneously. The patient does not use tobacco or illicit substances. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals mild sensory loss in both legs below the knees. The left foot shows an extensor plantar reflex. Which of the following pathologic brain lesions is most likely present in this patient?

choices.text: Focal areas of demyelination with macrophages containing myelin debris
Extracellular senile plaques and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles
Necrosis of rapidly proliferating, anaplastic glial cells
Accumulation of nuclear viral inclusions within enlarged oligodendrocytes
Axonal demyelination in pontine white matter

questions.solution:
This young woman is presenting with classic signs and symptoms (e.g., urinary incontinence, optic neuritis, paresthesias) of multiple sclerosis (MS). MS is a chronic, degenerative disease of the central nervous system that results from an autoimmune-mediated attack against oligodendrocytes. The exact etiology of MS is unclear; however, there is a genetic predisposition to the condition (HLA-DR2), as well as identifiable triggers, such as vitamin D deficiency and cigarette smoking. Vitamin D deficiency can explain why the rate of MS is higher among people who live further from the equator, where there is less sunlight.  

The lesions in MS are caused by a type IV hypersensitivity (cell-mediated reaction) in which Th1 and Th17 T-cells react against myelin antigens and secrete cytokines, which dilate the blood vessels, allowing more immune cells to extravasate from the bloodstream, as well as directly cause damage to oligodendrocytes. The cytokines attract B-cells, which begin to make antibodies that target the myelin. Macrophages are able to identify these antibodies and attack the marked oligodendrocytes. Without oligodendrocytes, there is no myelin to cover the neurons, leaving behind areas of scar tissue, also called plaques.   





Option Analysis

✅ Focal areas of demyelination with macrophages containing myelin debris:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Extracellular senile plaques and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles:
Incorrect: Neuritic plaques and neurofibrillary tangles are typically seen in patients with Alzheimer disease. The condition presents in elderly individuals with an insidious onset and is characterized by slow, progressive short term memory loss. In later stages, there are also behavioral and personality changes. 
❌ Necrosis of rapidly proliferating, anaplastic glial cells :
Incorrect: Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is a highly malignant primary brain tumor. Due to its rapid growth, there is often a central area of necrosis and hemorrhage. Patients may present with epileptic seizures, as well as signs of an elevated intracranial pressure (e.g., headaches, vomiting, papilledema). The episodic nature of this patient’s disease makes GBM an unlikely diagnosis. 
❌ Accumulation of nuclear viral inclusions within enlarged oligodendrocytes:
Incorrect: This finding is suggestive of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). PML is caused by JC virus, a polyomavirus, which infects oligodendrocytes resulting in demyelination and neuronal death. PML typically occurs in patients who are immunosuppressed (e.g. HIV patients) and typically presents as progressive encephalopathy. In contrast, this patient is not immunosuppressed and has episodic symptoms, making PML unlikely. 
❌ Axonal demyelination in pontine white matter:
Incorrect: Osmotic demyelination syndrome, also known as central pontine myelinolysis, occurs secondary to rapid osmotic changes, most commonly in the setting of correction of hyponatremia. Patients typically present with acute paralysis, dysphagia, and loss of consciousness. In contrast, this patient is presenting with a more episodic disease course, making osmotic demyelination syndrome unlikely.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the primary care physician complaining of urinary urgency for the past week with occasional involuntary voiding, which has been causing the patient significant distress at work. She states this has never happened before, but that several months ago, she went to the emergency department for an episode of intense right eye pain with movement and loss of color vision. These symptoms gradually improved over 2 weeks. She has no other past medical history. Vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmologic examination reveals no visual field defects. Physical examination reveals upgoing plantar reflexes bilaterally. A head MRI shows multiple hyperintense periventricular ovoid lesions. Which of the following best describes the likely disease course in this patient?

choices.text: Symptom exacerbations with near complete recovery between episodes
Continuous worsening from the onset of the disease
Symptom exacerbations with worsening of symptoms between episodes
Rapidly progressive disease course with neurologic disability in 5 years
Fully functional in all neurologic systems 15 years after the disease onset

questions.solution:
This woman is presenting with various neurologic symptoms (e.g., urgency incontinence, optic neuritis, positive Babinski sign) and has an MRI scan showing periventricular lesions. She most likely has multiple sclerosis (MS).

Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune demyelinating disease that results in oligodendrocyte damage and depletion. The previous episode of optic neuritis was likely caused by plaque formation around the optic nerve. The current urgency incontinence occurs due to detrusor overactivity secondary to cortical demyelinating lesions that impair the detrusor reflex at the level of the frontal cortex.  

There are various clinical courses that MS can follow, with relapsing-remitting MS (RR-MS) the most common; it is the clinical course of 90% of patients at the time of diagnosis. RR-MS describes a disease course characterized by clearly defined attacks (also called exacerbations or relapses) with full or near-full recovery in between. This patient had a prior episode of optic neuritis that resolved spontaneously and is now presenting with urgency incontinence that will also likely resolve spontaneously. As the plaques worsen, so too will the neurologic dysfunctions, and eventually RR-MS will become secondary progressive MS in 50% of patients, wherein there is continuous worsening of symptoms between exacerbations.    



Option Analysis

✅ Symptom exacerbations with near complete recovery between episodes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Continuous worsening from the onset of the disease:
Incorrect: Primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PP-MS) describes a clinical course with no acute exacerbations but with continuous worsening of symptoms from the very onset of the disease. However, this patient’s history is notable for acute episodes of MS followed by complete resolution of symptoms, which is inconsistent with the presentation of PP-MS. 
❌ Symptom exacerbations with worsening of symptoms between episodes:
Incorrect: Secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (MS) describes a clinical course with continuous worsening of symptoms in between exacerbations. However, this is not the most common clinical course of MS. Moreover, although relapsing-remitting MS eventually becomes secondary progressive MS, this transition usually occurs 10 to 20 years after disease onset. 
❌ Rapidly progressive disease course with neurologic disability in 5 years:
Incorrect: Malignant multiple sclerosis (MS), also known as aggressive MS, describes a rapidly progressive disease course that leads to debilitating neurologic dysfunction within 5 to 10 years. This is not the most common disease course of MS. 
❌ Fully functional in all neurologic systems 15 years after the disease onset:
Incorrect: Benign multiple sclerosis describes a disease course wherein patients experience a single demyelinating event, but will never experience a second exacerbation. This is a rare type of multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of intermittent numbness and tingling in both legs for the past several weeks. The patient is an attorney and has been under stress while working on a “career-defining case.” Past medical history is significant for an episode of urinary incontinence 5 months ago, as well as a transient episode of unilateral blurry vision last year. Both episodes resolved spontaneously. Vital signs are within normal limits. On an attempted left gaze, the left eye abducts but the right eye remains stationary. The patient is able to converge both eyes with no difficulty. Muscle strength in the right and left lower extremities are 3/5. Ankle reflexes are 3+ on both sides, and plantar reflexes are upgoing. Lower extremity sensation to vibration, light touch, and pain is decreased bilaterally. Which of the following additional complaints is this patient likely to present with in the future?

choices.text: Exacerbation of neurological symptoms following physical activity
Excessive pruritus after a hot shower
Fever with concurrent headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status
Worsening delusions and hallucinations
Bilateral pupils that accommodate but do not react to light

questions.solution:
This young woman presenting with various neurological signs likely has multiple sclerosis (MS). MS should be suspected in patients with ≥ 2 distinctive episodes of central nervous system dysfunction that cannot be explained by a singular lesion. Common clinical features of multiple sclerosis include:  

- Optic neuritis: impaired vision, color blindness, painful eye movements, and afferent pupillary defect  
- Internuclear ophthalmoplegia: demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) that results in ipsilateral medial rectus weakness but an intact convergence reflex  
- Autonomic dysfunction: impaired sexual activity, and bowel and bladder dysfunction 
- Cerebellar dysfunction: ataxia, intention tremor, and nystagmus (Charcot triad)  
- Lhermitte sign: a shooting electric sensation that travels down the spine when the patient flexes the neck
- Uhthoff phenomenon: exacerbation of neurological symptoms following an increase in core body temperature (e.g., following physical activity, a warm bath, fever)

In early MS, the neurological dysfunctions most commonly have a relapsing-remitting quality, which is characterized by clearly defined attacks followed by full or partial recovery. In between the attacks, there is no progression of the symptoms.   

Option Analysis

✅ Exacerbation of neurological symptoms following physical activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Excessive pruritus after a hot shower:
Incorrect: Symptoms of multiple sclerosis (e.g., numbness, tingling, incontinence) can exacerbate with increases in body temperature. This is termed Uhthoff’s phenomenon. However, excess pruritis after a hot shower is more characteristic of aquagenic pruritus, which is typically seen in patients with polycythemia vera.
❌ Fever with concurrent headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status:
Incorrect: Untreated Lyme disease can progress to stage III (neuroborreliosis), which may present similarly to multiple sclerosis. Clinical symptoms of neuroborreliosis include gait abnormality, cognitive impairment, and bladder dysfunction. Aseptic meningitis, which can present with fever, headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status, however, would only be seen in patients with Lyme disease.
❌ Worsening delusions and hallucinations:
Incorrect: Psychosis can be the result of various conditions, such as schizophrenia and mania. MS patients, however, do not typically present with psychosis; instead, depression is the most common psychiatric complication in MS patients. 
❌ Bilateral pupils that accommodate but do not react to light:
Incorrect: Argyll-Robertson pupils, which are characterized by pupils that accommodate to near vision but do not react to light, are pathognomonic for neurosyphilis. Syphilis can present similarly to MS with ataxia and loss of peripheral sensation; however, syphilis can be differentiated by recognition of earlier signs, such as a painless genital ulcer in primary syphilis and a disseminated rash involving the palms and soles in secondary syphilis.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female is brought to the emergency department in a wheelchair due to difficulty walking. Several days ago, she had back pain and a tingling sensation of the toes. Eventually, she had an inability to move her feet and then her legs. Additionally, she reports being constipated for the past week. Three weeks ago, she had the flu, which was treated with over-the-counter medications and resolved on its own. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg while sitting. After standing assisted for several minutes, the blood pressure is 104/60 mmHg. Physical examination reveals absent ankle and knee reflexes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: CD8+ lymphocyte-mediated endoneurial inflammation
Perimysial inflammation with an abundance of CD4+ T-cells
Endomysial inflammation with an abundance of CD8+ T-cells
Thymic germinal centers producing antibodies against neurotransmitter receptors
IgG antibody-mediated destruction of presynaptic channels

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with bilateral, ascending paralysis and autonomic dysfunction after a preceding viral infection (e.g. influenza). She likely has Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS).  

Nearly two-thirds of patients with GBS experience symptoms of upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection 2-4 weeks prior to the onset of GBS. It is thought that these infectious agents have ganglioside-like molecules on their surface that are similar to the ganglioside components of myelin; this molecular mimicry results in production of cross-reactive antibodies against myelin in peripheral Schwann cells, resulting in immune-mediated segmental demyelination and an endoneurial inflammatory infiltrate composed of lymphocytes and macrophages.  

Clinical features of GBS correlate with the peripheral nerves that are affected. Pain due to nerve root inflammation, typically located in the back and extremities, is often an early feature of the condition. As symptoms progress, there is ascending, bilateral flaccid paralysis that spreads from the lower to upper limbs. This can present as severe weakness and absent deep tendon reflexes. Autonomic dysfunction can result in constipation and orthostatic hypotension. Most importantly, the paralysis may ascend to involve the diaphragm, causing shortness of breath and potentially respiratory failure, which is an emergency and is the most common cause of death in patients with GBS.    

Option Analysis

✅ CD8+ lymphocyte-mediated endoneurial inflammation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perimysial inflammation with an abundance of CD4+ T-cells:
Incorrect: Dermatomyositis is characterized by antibody-mediated inflammation of perimysial muscle fibers with an abundance of CD4+ T cells. Patients typically present with proximal muscle weakness and tenderness, as well as Gottron papules (erythematous papules on the extensor surface of the hands) and heliotrope rash (erythematous rash on the upper eyelids). It is classically seen in patients with an underlying malignancy; the lack of dermatologic symptoms in this patient makes this diagnosis unlikely. 
❌ Endomysial inflammation with an abundance of CD8+ T-cells:
Incorrect: Polymyositis is characterized by cell-mediated inflammation of endomysial muscle fibers with an abundance of CD8+ T cells. Similar to dermatomyositis, patients present with prominent proximal muscle weakness and tenderness. This patient’s bilateral, ascending paralysis is not likely to be the result of this condition. 
❌ Thymic germinal centers producing antibodies against neurotransmitter receptors:
Incorrect: Myasthenia gravis (MG) can be seen in patients with a thymoma. The condition is characterized by production of autoreactive antibodies directed against postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors. Patients typically present with eye muscle weakness, bulbar muscle weakness (e.g., slurred speech, difficulty chewing/swallowing), and proximal limb weakness that worsens with repeated use and improves with rest. This patient’s bilateral, ascending paralysis is not likely to be the result of MG.
❌ IgG antibody-mediated destruction of presynaptic channels:
Incorrect: Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is a condition wherein autoantibodies are directed against presynaptic calcium channels. Symptoms are similar to those of MG, but muscle weakness improves throughout the day with repeated use. Autonomic dysfunction is also prominent in LEMS. This patient's bilateral ascending paralysis after a viral infection, however, is not likely to be the result of LEMS.
